State Key Laboratory of Advanced Technology for Materials Synthesis and Processing Wuhan University of Technology Luoshi Road 122 Wuhan 430070 PR China Graphical abstract Photocatalytic CO2 reduction for solar fuel production has received enormous attention due to its ability for solving both energy crisis and CO2 pollution. However, fabrication of cheap and efficient materials for photocatalytic CO2 reduction is still challenging. Herein, TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) in situ grew on highly conductive MXene Ti3C2 through calcination method. And a unique rice crust-like structure was achieved through the uniform distribution of TiO2 nanoparticles on Ti3C2. This optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 composite exhibited a 3.7 times higher photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance for CH4-production (0.22 μmol h−1) than commercial TiO2 (P25). The detailed photocatalytic CO2 reduction mechanism using TiO2/Ti3C2 was confirmed through the 13CO2 isotopic test and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy. Experimental evidence along with preliminary calculation was also used to further elucidate the proposed photocatalytic enhancement mechanism. This extraordinary photocatalytic performance was due to the unique morphology and the features of individual components in the composite. Namely, fluffy rice crust-like structure of the prepared samples rendered the composite with large population of the surface-active sites. Ultrahigh conductivity of Ti3C2 facilitated the photogenerated electron transfer and suppressed its recombination with photogenerated holes. This work presents a simple method to prepare highly efficient TiO2/Ti3C2 composite for photoconversion applications. Keywords MXenes Ti3C2 TiO2 Photocatalysis CO2 reduction 1 Introduction Due to the rapid growth in the industry and human population, fossil fuels such as coal, petroleum and natural gas have been vastly consumed, causing energy crisis and environmental problems [1–6]. To address these problems, artificial photosynthesis through photocatalytic CO2 reduction in the presence of H2O has attracted wide attention due to its potential in converting greenhouse gases, i.e. CO2, into valuable chemical fuels through various chemical reactions [7–11]. Formic acid (CH2O2), formaldehyde (CH2O), and methane (CH4) are three of countless representative chemical fuels [12–17]. In this context, various semiconductors such as TiO2, CdS, g-C3N4, BiOBr and Fe3O4, have been extensively studied and investigated for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [18–23]. Among them, TiO2 is the first candidate and still a benchmark because of its effectiveness, environmental friendliness and photostability [24–27]. However, it still remains challenging to achieve the practical application of TiO2 for photocatalytic CO2 reduction mainly due to its low light utilization ability and rapid electron-hole recombination [28–31]. Thus, enormous strategies, (for instance, surface modification, co-catalyst loading, impurity doping and heterojunction construction) have been proposed to enhance the photocatalytic performance of TiO2 [32–34]. Two-dimensional (2D) layered materials have been widely studied due to their extraordinary physical and chemical properties [35–37]. Especially, studies on graphene analogues such as g-C3N4 and MoS2 have bloomed in the past decade. Recently, the discovery of 2D MXenes (e.g., Ti3C2, Ti2C, Nb2C, V2C and Mo2C) by Gogotsi et al. has reignited scientific interest in preparing 2D layered materials [38–40]. Generally, MXene is a layer of transition metal carbides and/or nitrides with a Mn+1AXn formula, where M is a transition metal, i.e. Ti, V, Mo; A is a group-XIII (or XIV) element and n is an integer from 1 to 3 [40,41]. Attributing to their high electrical conductivity, large specific surface area, hydrophilicity and compositional variability, MXenes have been intensively investigated and applied for various applications, not confined to supercapacitors, batteries, water filtration, catalysis and antibacterial films [42–44]. The photocatalytic application of MXene Ti3C2 has also been investigated by Qiao and co-workers [45], indicating that photocatalytic H2-production performance of CdS was enhanced using Ti3C2 as cocatalyst due to its high conductivity. Herein, the design motif was the grafting of TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) on the MXene Ti3C2 by a simple calcination method. Advances of the in situ growth allowed for the intimate contact and portrayed a unique rice crust like structure, endowing it with large specific surface area. The loading amount of TiO2 NPs on Ti3C2 can be tailored by adjusting the calcination temperature. Moreover, after careful investigation, the high electronic conductivity of the Ti3C2 was found to be beneficial for the migration of photogenerated electrons from TiO2 to Ti3C2, achieving spatial separation of electron-hole pairs. The photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance of the optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 composite was 3.7 times higher than that of commercial TiO2 (P25) due to the enlarged specific surface area and enhanced electron-hole separation efficiency. This simple and effective method was highlighted to enhance the photocatalytic performance of TiO2, providing fertile ground for the potential applications of MXene-based materials in photocatalysis. 2 Experimental details 2.1 Sample preparation 2.1.1 Materials All chemical reagents (analytical grade) were purchased from Shanghai Chemical Reagent Factory of China without further purification. Deionized (DI) water was used in all experiments. 2.1.2 Preparation of Ti3C2 Ti3C2 was prepared according to a previous report [46]. Two grams of as-purchased Ti3AlC2 powders were dispersed in 40 ml HF solution. The obtained dispersion was stirred at room temperature for 48 h to remove Al layer, obtaining Ti3C2. The slurry was then filtered and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Then, Ti3C2 powders were intercalated by polar organic molecules using 30 ml dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) solution. The mixture was then kept stirring for 24 h. Thereafter, the obtained solution underwent sonication for 1 h to obtain ultrathin 2D layered Ti3C2 [47,48]. 2.1.3 Preparation of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite TiO2/Ti3C2 composite was obtained by a simple calcination method. Typically, the above-prepared Ti3C2 solution was dried at 80 °C for 12 h. Then, the dried Ti3C2 were calcined at 350 °C, 450 °C, 550 °C and 650 °C with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min to obtain TT350, TT450, TT550 and TT650, respectively. Finally, the obtained samples were grinded and collected. The dried Ti3C2 without calcination were used as the controlled sample and labeled as TT0. 2.2 Characterization The phase structures of the prepared samples were investigated through X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns recorded on a D/Max-RB X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan) using CuKα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) with a scan rate of 0.05°(2θ) s−1. The elemental analysis was carried out on Vario EL cube through the dry combustion method. Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) (JSM-7500F, JEOL, Japan) was applied to determine the morphologies of the prepared samples. Oxford Instruments X-ray analysis system equipped on JSM-7500F was used to carry out the energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy and elemental mapping test. Titan G2 60–300 microscope operated at 300 kV was used to obtain the transmission electron microscope (TEM) images of the prepared samples. The thickness and surface topology for single layer Ti3C2 of TT0 were determined using an an atomic force microscopy (AFM, Multimode 8 AFM, Bruker, Germany) under ScanAnalyst mode with cantilevers at a spring constant of 0.35 N m−1 and a frequency of 65 kHz. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (JPS-9010MC, JEOL, Japan) characterization was performed with a hemispherical electron energy analyzer (1486 eV Al Kα radiation) to determine the surface composition and chemical status of the prepared samples. The binding energy of all prepared samples was calibrated with the C 1s peak of C–C (284.8 eV). Raman analysis was carried out on Raman spectrometer (Renishaw InVia) with back-scattering geometry and 514.5 nm laser excitation. UV–visible spectrophotometer (UV-2600, Shimadzu, Japan) was used to record the light absorption spectra of the prepared samples. BaSO4 was used as reflectance reference for UV–visible spectrophotometer. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm was obtained on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 nitrogen adsorption apparatus (USA) to determine the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) specific surface area (S BET) of the prepared samples through a multipoint BET method using the adsorption data at the relative pressure (P/P 0) range of 0.05–0.3. Prior to the test, the samples were degassed at 180 °C. The pore size distribution of the prepared samples was calculated through the Barret-Joyner-Halender (BJH) method. The pore volume and average pore size of the prepared samples were determined using the adsorbed nitrogen volume at the relative pressure of 0.994. 2.3 Electrochemical measurement and photocatalytic performance test The electrochemical measurement was performed on standard three-electrode electrochemical analyzer (CHI660C instruments, CHI, China) system using low power UV-LED (3 W, 365 nm) as light source. During the electrochemical test, 30 ml 0.5 M Na2SO4 aqueous solution was used as electrolyte. Meanwhile, the prepared sample (with a geometrical area of 1.0 cm2), Pt wire and Ag|AgCl immersed in the filling solution (saturated KCl) were respectively utilized as working, counter and reference electrodes in this electrochemical analyzer system. Photocatalytic performance of the prepared samples was investigated through photocatalytic CO2 reduction test. The photocatalytic CO2 reduction test was carried out in a 200 ml Pyrex reactor at room temperature. Prior to the reaction, 50 mg of the prepared sample was ultrasonically dispersed in deionized water and poured into the Pyrex reactor. Then, the dispersion was dried at 80 °C for 6 h to create a thin film at the bottom of Pyrex reactor. Thereafter, the Pyrex reactor was sealed and flowed with the nitrogen gas for 30 min to achieve the anaerobic condition. The reaction between 84 mg NaHCO3 (added into the reactor before sealing) and 0.3 ml 4 M HCl (excess HCl solution, added into the reactor by syringe after sealing) was applied to in situ generate CO2 and H2O vapor within the system. The detailed reaction between NaHCO3 and HCl is as follows, (1) NaHC O 3 + HCl = NaCl + H 2 O + C O 2 Then, 300 W simulated solar Xe arc lamp (see Fig. S1 for the spectral distribution) was used as light source and placed vertically 10 cm above the Pyrex reactor. After 1 h of light irradiation, 1 ml of gas was taken out from the reactor and analyzed. Gas chromatograph (PGC-80, Changzhou Panna Instrument, China) equipped with flame ionized detector (FID) and methanizer was used to determine the composition of resultant gas. High purity nitrogen gas was applied as carrier gas in the PGC-80. Gas chromatography–mass spectrometry (GC–MS) was carried out to confirm the origin of the hydrocarbon compounds produced during photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The above-mentioned CO2 reduction test was also carried out during GC–MS characterization except that the CO2 and H2O vapor were generated by NaHCO3 with different C-labelling. NaHCO3-12C and NaHCO3-13C were selectively used during photocatalytic 12CO2 and 13CO2 reduction test, respectively. GC–MS (6980N network GC system–5975 inert mass selective detector, Agilent technologies, USA) was used to determine the mixed gas (250 μL) taken out from the reactor after 1 h of photocatalytic reaction. Nicolet iS50 infrared Fourier transform spectrometer (TMO, USA) was used to record in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of the prepared samples. Prior to the test, the prepared samples were degassed at 150 °C for 6 h and placed into the reaction chamber of DRIFTS. Then, the chamber was sealed and purged with the mixed CO2 and H2O vapor. The DRIFTS was carried out under dark condition (3 cycles, 20 min each) and 3 W 365 nm LED light irradiation (3 cycles, 20 min each). 2.4 Material simulation Density functional theory (DFT) simulation was performed using Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) module in Materials Studio software [49]. The Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) version of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to optimize the geometry structures [50]. The norm-conserving pseudopotentials were performed for simulating interaction between valence electrons and ionic core. Van der Waals interactions were considered using Grimme empirical correction [51]. An optimized 500 eV cut-off energy was selected after testing higher kinetic cut-off energies for confirming the accuracy of the simulations. The Monkhorst-Pack k-point grid was set as 3 × 3 × 1 for the Brillouin zone. A vacuum space of 15 Å was built to avoid the interference of neighboring systems along the c axis. The convergence standards for the electronic structure iteration were 1.0 × 10−5 eV/atom for energy, 0.03 eV Å−1 for max force, 0.005 GPa for max pressure and 0.001 Å for max displacement. The electronic structures of TiO2 and Ti3C2 were calculated by HSE06 hybrid functional to avoid underestimation in bandgap for PBE of GGA exchange correlation function. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Phase structures The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 1 a. Obviously, after reaction with the HF, the diffraction line for the (1 0 4) planes of TT0 at 39° disappeared in comparison with Ti3AlC2, indicating the transformation from Ti3AlC2 to Ti3C2 after elimination of the Al layers by HF etching [52,53]. Moreover, it can be found that the position of the (0 0 4) planes of TT0 shifted to a lower angle after HF etching and DMSO delamination due to an increase in the interlayer spacing of the Ti3C2, indicating the successful exfoliation of Ti3C2 [54]. After calcination of Ti3C2 at 350 °C, the diffraction lines assigned to the Ti3C2 were intensified due to an increase in the crystallinity of Ti3C2. Furthermore, new diffraction lines assigned to anatase TiO2 can be observed, suggesting the successful transformation of Ti3C2 into TiO2. As the calcination temperature further increased, the diffraction line intensity of TiO2 gradually increased due to an increase in the TiO2 content, increase in TiO2 crystallinity and decrease in the surface defects of the samples. The shrink in surface defects reduced the likelihood of electron-hole pair recombination. Moreover, in TT350, TT450 and TT550, in the range between 30° and 50° (Fig. 1b), the diffraction lines of the Ti3C2 located at 35° and 43° were still retained, confirming the formation of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. In addition, the intensity of diffraction lines of the Ti3C2 were found to be decreased with increasing calcination temperature due to the transformation of Ti3C2 into the TiO2. The ratio of TiO2 to Ti3C2 was estimated using elemental analysis (listed in Table S1), and it is positively correlated with calcination temperature. At 650 °C, Ti3C2 was fully transformed into TiO2. This result further confirmed that the loading amount of TiO2 can be simply tuned by changing the calcination temperature. Raman spectra, shown in Fig. 2 , further reveal the constituents of the prepared samples. For the Ti2AlC and TT0 (Fig. 2 inset), several characteristic bands appeared at ca. 175, 260, 410 and 605 cm−1, attributed to the ω 1, ω 2, ω 3, and ω 4 Raman-active phonon vibration modes [55]. Noticeably, the ω3 Raman band modes of TT0 are blue-shifted in comparison with that of Ti2AlC. This shift was due to the presence of interlayer adsorbents and delamination of Ti3AlC2 by HF etching and DMSO delamination [56]. For Raman spectra of TT550 and TT650, several characteristic bands attributed to E g (144 cm−1), B 1g (400 cm−1), A 1g (514 cm−1) and E g (650 cm−1) modes of anatase TiO2 can be observed, suggesting the transformation of Ti3C2 into TiO2 during calcination. 3.2 Morphology As shown in Fig. 3 a and b, the prepared TT0 exhibited a hierarchical accordion-like structure. The thickness of the single layer Ti3C2 obtained by ultrasonication was determined to be ca. 1.6 nm through AFM characterization (Fig. S2). However, a visualized single layer in SEM (see Fig. 3a and b) was about 5–10 nm, suggesting a stacking of several single layers. It should be noted that a lot of nanoparticles can be found on the edge of the TT0. These nanoparticles were amorphous TiO2 NPs which were formed due to the introduction of strong oxidation agent (viz. DMSO) during the delamination of Ti3C2. The surface of Ti3C2 became rougher (Fig. 3c and d) after calcination, which was attributed to the formation of TiO2 NPs on the surface of Ti3C2. Notably, TiO2 NPs with the size of ca. 25 nm were uniformly dispersed on Ti3C2. This was because in situ transformation of the Ti3C2 into TiO2 can inhibit the agglomeration and thus preserve the uniform size distribution of the TiO2 NPs. In addition, the oxidation of the Ti3C2 into TiO2 can also cause enlargement of interspace between TiO2 laminar due to the increased crystal size of the prepared samples. Interestingly, the morphology of TT550 was fluffy and similar to that of the rice crust (see Fig. 3c inset). Particularly, although these TiO2 nanoparticles were interconnected, a lot of air voids existed in between (see Fig. S3a and b), increasing the specific surface area of the samples. The presence of these unique air voids on the TT550 was attributed to the production of CO2 gas during the calcination process. However, further increase in the calcination temperature to 650 °C caused the reduction in the air void density due to the increase in the size of the TiO2 NPs (Fig. 3e and f). Moreover, a lot of cracks can be found on TT650 (see Fig. S3c and d). The formation of these cracks was due to the incompatibility of their respective surface tension. Furthermore, the information regarding the elemental composition and the distribution of elements on prepared samples were determined by elemental mapping test using energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) (see Fig. S4). As shown in Fig. S4a, Ti, O, C, and F elements can be observed, indicating the presence of Ti3C2, TiO2 and residue F− ions on the TT0. After calcination (Fig. S4b–e), the F element disappeared due to the removal of F− ions at high temperature. Moreover, it can be found that the content of O element increased with increasing calcination temperature. Oppositely, the content of C element decreased and disappeared at 650 °C. This result was on account of the gradual transformation from Ti3C2 into TiO2 during calcination, in good agreement with the XRD results. The TEM and HRTEM images of TT550 are shown in Fig. 4 . As shown in Fig. 4a, the TiO2 NPs were attached to Ti3C2, forming a sandwich-like structure. This result indicated that the transformation from Ti3C2 to TiO2 began from the surface and extended to the core of the Ti3C2. The clearly-observed lattice fringes of the TiO2 and Ti3C2 (see Fig. 4b) suggested successful preparation of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. In detail, the lattice fringes of 3.45 Å and 2.70 Å were attributed to the (1 0 1) planes of anatase TiO2 and (0 1 ¯ 10) planes of Ti3C2, respectively. Interestingly, the Ti3C2 nanosheets were sandwiched between the TiO2 NPs, further confirming the sandwich structure of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. The sandwich structure of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite was beneficial for providing more contact interface to accelerate the charge carrier migration between them. 3.3 Optical property Comparison of the light absorption spectra of the prepared samples is shown in Fig. 5 . TT0 exhibited the highest light absorption from 300 to 700 nm due to the black color nature of Ti3C2. TT350 exhibited similar optical properties with slightly reduced light absorption intensity because a small portion of the Ti3C2 was converted into TiO2. Obvious light absorption edges at ca. 400 nm can be found for samples calcinated at temperature higher than 450 °C, due to the intrinsic light absorption of the TiO2, confirming the emergence of TiO2. Also, there is a decrease in light absorption intensity of the samples in the visible-light range (>400 nm) with calcination temperature rising. This trend was in accordance with the gradual color changes of the prepared samples from dark black (TT0) to white (TT650) (inset of Fig. 5). These changes reinforced the changes in Ti3C2 content, in line with previous XRD and EDS results. Generally, a higher content of the Ti3C2 generated a stronger light absorption at visible-light range. Although this Ti3C2-induced light absorption enhancement cannot be directly applied for the generation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, the accompanying photothermal effect on the samples is beneficial for accelerating the reactant adsorption-desorption and charge carrier migration [57]. However, for TT650, the light absorption of the samples at visible-light range almost vanished due to a fully transformation of Ti3C2 into TiO2. 3.4 Surface composition As evidenced in the previous sections, the surface composition of the prepared samples would greatly change after the calcination due to the oxidation of Ti3C2. To further confirm the changes of the surface compositions and chemical states of the prepared samples, the XPS characterization was carried out. The survey spectra of three typical samples TT0, TT550 and TT650 are compared in Fig. 6 a. Obviously, three samples exhibited the binding energy peaks of Ti element. An extra F peak can only be found on TT0 due to the residue F− ions from the HF solution, suggesting its complete removal in the TT550 and TT650 samples, coincided well with EDS results [58]. As shown in Fig. 6b, 8 different peaks can be found in the high resolution Ti 2p, which is in accordance with the previous report of Ti3C2 [59,60]. In contrast, only two main binding energy peaks originating from TiO2 can be observed for TT550 and TT650 (see Fig. 6c); whilst Ti3C2 binding energy peak can hardly be found, which seems to be in contradiction with XRD characterization. This was because XPS technique can only examine the composition of the surface layer (less than 5 nm depth) [61], making it difficult to detect the Ti3C2 sandwiched by TiO2 NPs (ca. 25 nm in size). Furthermore, the C 1s XPS spectrum of TT0 XPS spectrum exhibited three obvious peaks at 286.6, 284.8 and 281.6 eV, designated to COC, CC and CTiOx, respectively. Those were attributed to the Ti3C2 and adventitious carbon (Fig. 6d) [60,62]. After calcination at 550 (Fig. 6e) and 650 °C (Fig. 6f), the peak attributed to CTiOx disappeared, manifesting the decrease in Ti3C2 content [59]. Furthermore, as shown in Fig. 6g–i, the intensity of CTiOx, CTiOHx and CO decreased; meanwhile, intensity of TiO increased with increasing calcination temperature, indicating the transformation of the Ti3C2 into the TiO2. 3.5 Physical and electrochemical properties The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and corresponding pore-size distribution curves of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 7 . Obviously, all the prepared samples exhibited type-IV isotherms according to the Brunauer-Deming-Deming-Teller (BDDT) classification, suggesting the presence of mesopores (2–50 nm). The isotherms at the higher relative pressure range (at the range 0.8–1.0) showed H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating the presence of slit-like pores [63]. In addition, high adsorption can also be observed at adsorption range approaching 1.0, demonstrating the presence of large mesopores and macropores. Apparently from the inset of Fig. 7, all the prepared samples manifested a wide range pore distribution from 2 to 100 nm, with a peak at ca. 20 nm, suggesting the presence of mesopores and macropores attributed to the stacking of the Ti3C2 nanosheets and air voids formed between TiO2 NPs. The aforementioned data in easily assimilated form was summarized in Table S1. The specific surface area increased linearly with calcination temperature before 550 °C. This was because in situ growth of TiO2 on Ti3C2 created a lot of air void within the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. In detail, these air voids were generated by the CO2 evolution during the calcination of the Ti3C2. However, further increase in calcination temperature from 550 to 650 °C reduced the specific surface area. This was because opposite trend of crystallinity and particle size met in an intermediate. The results suggest the importance of precise control of the calcination temperature to optimize the physical property of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. Furthermore, the electrochemical surface area (ECSA) characterization can also shed light on the physical properties of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. In a typical ECSA test, the surface area of a material is measured through electrochemical double layer capacitance (EDLC) which can be investigated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) (see Fig. S5a and b). As shown in Fig. S5a, TT450, TT550 and TT650 exhibited similar CV curves, suggesting their similar electrochemical properties. However, the Ti3C2 dominated samples (TT0 and TT350) revealed severe polarization (see Fig. S5b). Then, ECSA curves of TT450, TT550 and TT650 were derived from CV curves using the halves of the positive and negative current density differences at the center point of their potential ranges (Fig. S5c). Obviously, ECSA of the prepared samples increased with increasing calcination temperature from 450 °C to 550 °C. The enlarged ECSA was in virtue of air voids, analogous to surface area increment. Additional temperature escalating was detrimental for the ESCA due to the grain coarsening. To investigate the generation and separation efficiency of the photogenerated charge carrier, the photocurrent response test was performed. Prior to the test, the linear sweep voltammetry test (Fig. S6) was carried out to confirm that the bias voltage used was 1.2 V during the photocurrent response test. As shown in Fig. 8 a, without light, photocurrent was indiscernible. Upon light irradiation, TT0 showed no difference because it was mainly constituted by non-semiconducting Ti3C2 (>85 wt%). Nevertheless, as for TT350, TT450, TT550 and TT650, significant photocurrent appeared, indicating that the efficient transfer of excited electrons to the cathode. Notably, these curves can be categorized into two types. Except TT650, other samples displayed similar photocurrent curves (represented by photocurrent curve i in Fig. 8a). Specifically, the photocurrents increased smoothly before levelling off when the light was on. To expound this phenomenon, we tentatively propose the mechanism. The photogenerated electrons on TiO2 preferred to migrate to Ti3C2 before reaching the cathode due to the high electronic conductivity of Ti3C2, achieving spatial separation of electron-hole pairs. Similarly, when turning off the light, the trend of photocurrent declining was stable, indicating the electron reservoir characteristic of the Ti3C2. Namely, the stored electrons on Ti3C2 gradually migrated to the cathode. The accumulation of the photogenerated electrons on Ti3C2 is beneficial for accelerating the multi-electron CO2 reduction reactions, such as: CO2 + 8H+ + 8e− → CH4 + 2H2O, −0.24 V vs. NHE at pH 7. Distinctively, TT650 exhibited a different behavior (see Fig. 8a photocurrent curve ii). On light irradiation, it evinced an anodic photocurrent spike, possibly due to direct migration of the photogenerated electron from TiO2 to the cathode. Afterwards, a reduction in photocurrent was explicit because the photogenerated holes on the TT650 tend to recombine with the photogenerated electrons due to the absence of Ti3C2. Subsequently, the photocurrent of TT650 dropped steeply to 0 after switching off the light. Overall, TT550 exhibited the highest photocurrent density among all the prepared samples, indicating that it had the highest electron-hole photogeneration efficiency and the lowest electron-hole recombination rate. Its superiority was ascribed to complex interplay of several factors: superior photogenerated electron-hole generation ability of TiO2 and suppressed electron-hole recombination rate devoted by highly conductive Ti3C2. Charge carrier migration process was further assessed by the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) characterization. The EIS Nyquist plots of the prepared samples are shown in Fig. 8b. Typically, the charge transfer resistance is reflected by the diameter of each semicircle. Obviously, the diameter became larger with increasing calcination temperature, indicating that the samples with higher Ti3C2 content exhibited lower charge transfer resistance. 3.6 Material simulations Furthermore, along with the experimental results, density functional theory (DFT) was employed to provide more insights into the preceding interpretation of the migration of photogenerated electrons from TiO2 to Ti3C2. The schematic atomic structures of the Ti3C2 and TiO2 are illustrated in Fig. 9 a and b. Obviously, a layered structure of Ti3C2 was formed by alternately arranging Ti and C atomic layers. The total and partial densities of states of the Ti3C2 are shown in Fig. 9c. Its conducting feature was authenticated by the overlap of conduction band with Fermi level, E F. E F is an important indicator related to electron accepting ability of a material. Generally, it is defined as follows: (2) E F = E vac - Φ where E vac and Φ are the energy of a stationary electron at vacuum level (assumed as 0 eV) and work function, respectively. The calculated electrostatic potential for the Ti3C2 is exhibited in Fig. 9d, in which the work function of Ti3C2 is 4.46 eV. Therefore, it can be estimated that the Fermi level of the Ti3C2 is located at −4.46 eV vs. vacuum level (−0.04 vs. normal hydrogen electrode (NHE)). To evaluate the charge migration between TiO2 and Ti3C2, the band edges of TiO2 were also estimated through following equations: (3) E VB = χ - E e + 0.5 E g (4) E CB = E VB - E g where χ, E e, E g, E CB and E VB are absolute electronegativity of TiO2 (5.8 eV), energy of free electron on the hydrogen scale (4.5 eV), bandgap of TiO2, conduction band edge position of TiO2 and valence band edge position of TiO2, respectively. The bandgap of the TiO2 was estimated to be 3.09 eV vs. NHE according to DFT simulation (Fig. 9e), in accordance with the light absorption spectrum of the pristine TiO2 (TT650). Based on the above equations, E CB of the TiO2 was calculated to be −0.25 eV vs. NHE, obviously, which was more negative than the Fermi level of the Ti3C2 (−0.04 eV vs. NHE) (see Fig. 9f), indicating that it is feasible for photogenerated electrons to migrate from TiO2 to Ti3C2. Notably, the difference between the conduction band edge position of TiO2 and Fermi level of the Ti3C2 was very small, effectively reducing the energy barrier for electron transfer. Therefore, the photogenerated electrons can easily migrate through the TiO2/Ti3C2 interface, achieving high electron-hole separation efficiency. 3.7 Photocatalytic performance To determine the photocatalytic performance of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite, we carried out photocatalytic CO2 reduction tests using different samples under light irradiation. The resultant products of photocatalytic CO2 reduction using prepared samples under 1 h light irradiation are shown in Fig. 10 . Obviously, CH4 was the main product for all the prepared samples along with small amounts of CH3OH and C2H5OH. The production of these compounds (CH4, CH3OH and C2H5OH) was thermodynamically feasible because the reduction potential of photogenerated electrons in TiO2 is −0.5 V vs. NHE at pH = 7 (see also Table 1 ) more negative than that of these compounds. Furthermore, the CH4 was the dominant product due to its reduction potential (−0.24 V vs. NHE at pH 7) less negative than that for CH3OH (−0.38 V vs. NHE at pH 7) and C2H5OH (−0.33 V vs. NHE at pH 7). The production of these valuable fuels using the prepared samples indicated the potential of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite in photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The origin of the carbon elements of the hydrocarbon compounds produced by photocatalytic CO2 reduction was confirmed by the isotope tracer analysis involving the photocatalytic reduction of different C-labelling CO2. The isotope tracer analysis was performed through photocatalytic reduction of 12C-labeled CO2 and 13C-labeled CO2 using TT550 using GC–MS. The resultant GC–MS spectra are presented in Fig. 11 . It was apparent that characteristic peaks at m/z = 16.1 (12CH4) and m/z = 17.1 (13CH4) were dominated in the GC–MS spectra of photocatalytic 12C-labeled CO2 and 13C-labeled CO2 reduction, respectively. This result validated that the labelling of the resultant CH4 was consistent with the labelling of the CO2, confirming that CO2 was the origin of the hydrocarbon compounds of the photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Comparison of the photocatalytic CH4 production rate using different prepared samples is shown in Fig. 12 a. CH4 production was difficult to observe for TT0 due to the high content of non-semiconducting Ti3C2. The photocatalytic performance of the prepared samples gradually improved with the rising of calcination temperature up to 550 °C due to an increase in TiO2 content. This was because TiO2 is a high performance photocatalyst for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. However, further raising calcination temperature to 650 °C deteriorated the photocatalytic performance. We owed this to the absence of Ti3C2, which causes rapid electron-hole recombination on TiO2, thereby worsening the photocatalytic performance. Besides, as already noticed, the specific surface area shrinking under high temperature was another important issue. These results reasserted the significance of calcination temperature for optimizing the photocatalytic performance of the TiO2/Ti3C2 composite. Indicator to quantify the improvement is highlighted: photocatalytic CH4 production rate (0.22 μmol h−1) of optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 composite (TT550) was ca. 3.7 times higher than that of commercial TiO2 (P25). In addition, this superior photocatalytic CH4 production performance of the optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 is also comparable with those of previous reported photocatalysts (see Table 2 ). Furthermore, the stability of the best sample TT550 was investigated (Fig. 12b). After 5 cycles, the photocatalytic CH4 production rate of the TT550 did not show pronounced change, indicating its excellent photostability. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was carried out to determine intermediate products for photocatalytic CO2 reduction using TT550. The DRIFTS characterization was performed under two conditions: dark condition (Fig. 13. C1) and light irradiation (Fig. 13.C2). Initially, under adsorption condition, various DRIFTS peaks of carbonate species can be observed on the DRIFTS spectra of TT550, suggesting its adsorption ability toward CO2 molecules. Over time, the DRIFTS peaks of HCOO, HCHO and CH3O appeared and intensified. It should be pointed out that the characteristic peak of CH4 was undetectable on the C2 part due to the nonpolar property of the CH4 [70,71]. The findings pinpointed that CO2 molecules were firstly adsorbed on the surface of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite and then transformed into assorted intermediate products composed of CH4, HCOO, HCO and CH3O. Based on previous results and discussion, the photocatalytic enhancement mechanism of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite for CO2 reduction is proposed and illustrated in Fig. 14 . Firstly, large specific surface area springing from intriguing morphology should take the credit. It not only ensures abundant surface-active sites, but also promotes CO2 adsorption ability. Secondly, individual components contribute to the comprehensive performance. The light adsorption of the composite is upgraded by the black color nature of Ti3C2, creating photothermal effect. Thirdly, in situ growth on conductive 2D Ti3C2 generates heterogeneous interfaces that can modify native material properties. Unlike weakly-adhered mechanically mixed materials, the intimate contact facilitates the charge carrier migration, achieving efficient electron-hole separation. Moreover, the accumulation of the photogenerated electrons on Ti3C2 is favorable for the multi-electron CO2 reduction reaction. In addition, it should be noted that three main products including CH4 (reduction potential at −0.24 V), C2H5OH (at −0.33 V) and CH3OH (at −0.38 V) can be obtained during the photocatalytic CO2 reduction due to the sufficiently high intrinsic reduction potential (−0.5 V vs. NHE at pH = 7) of the TiO2 (see Table 1). Although the coupling of the Ti3C2 with TiO2 NPs is beneficial for photocatalytic CO2 reduction, we should always keep in mind that an excess of Ti3C2 can cause adverse effect on the photocatalytic performance. An excess of Ti3C2 leads to the light shielding effect. In detail, Ti3C2 would compete with TiO2 NPs to absorb the incident photons, significantly suppressing the photoconversion efficiency of the TiO2 NPs. Therefore, the control over the ratio of TiO2 NPs to Ti3C2 is crucial to achieve optimized photocatalytic performance of the composite. We envisioned a paradigm of material design which can effectively tune this vital ratio. This method is expected to be extended to prepare other MXene/metal oxide composites. 4 Conclusion In summary, the design concept is the in situ growth of TiO2 NPs on the MXene Ti3C2 by a simple calcination method. Strong evidences have demonstrated the successful preparation and modulation on the loading ratio of TiO2 NPs. Since we are interested in investigating the consequences of this unique synthesis, we focus our studies on the ratio and probing its effect on photocatalytic performance. The photocatalytic CH4 production rate of the optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 (TT550) was ca. 2.8 and 3.7 times higher than that of the pure TiO2 (TT650) and P25, respectively. The underlying mechanism is proposed. The electron reservoir characteristic of the Ti3C2 can greatly suppress the electron-hole recombination on TiO2 NPs and enhance the accumulation of electron for multi-electron reaction. Moreover, the intimate contact benefiting from in situ growth is crucial for accelerating the photogenerated electrons transfer from TiO2 to Ti3C2. The large specific surface area of the unique rice crust-like multilayer configuration of TiO2/Ti3C2 composite governs in providing enormous surface-active sites for photocatalytic reaction. We hope that this work can herald the advent for other MXene-based composites for photoconversion applications. coredata.dc:description: Photocatalytic CO2 reduction for solar fuel production has received enormous attention due to its ability for solving both energy crisis and CO2 pollution. However, fabrication of cheap and efficient materials for photocatalytic CO2 reduction is still challenging. Herein, TiO2 nanoparticles (NPs) in situ grew on highly conductive MXene Ti3C2 through calcination method. And a unique rice crust-like structure was achieved through the uniform distribution of TiO2 nanoparticles on Ti3C2. This optimized TiO2/Ti3C2 composite exhibited a 3.7 times higher photocatalytic CO2 reduction performance for CH4-production (0.22 μmol h−1) than commercial TiO2 (P25). The detailed photocatalytic CO2 reduction mechanism using TiO2/Ti3C2 was confirmed through the 13CO2 isotopic test and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy. Experimental evidence along with preliminary calculation was also used to further elucidate the proposed photocatalytic enhancement mechanism. This extraordinary photocatalytic performance was due to the unique morphology and the features of individual components in the composite. Namely, fluffy rice crust-like structure of the prepared samples rendered the composite with large population of the surface-active sites. Ultrahigh conductivity of Ti3C2 facilitated the photogenerated electron transfer and suppressed its recombination with photogenerated holes. This work presents a simple method to prepare highly efficient TiO2/Ti3C2 composite for photoconversion applications.
